He created it to try to replicate MatLab‚Äôs (another programming language) plotting capabilities in Python. So if you are familiar with MatLab, matplotlib will feel natural to you. It is an excellent 2D and 3D graphics library for generating scientific figures.

Matplotlib allows you to create reproducible figures programmatically. Let‚Äôs learn how to use it! Before continuing this lecture, I encourage you just to explore the official Matplotlib web page: http://matplotlib.org/

>> pip install matplotlib

You are suitable to come here during the day when the eye of the heart is above your head, because it will emit light and refract optimally, in the afternoon the refraction of the light will begin to fade.
That's an interesting tourist spot and is in a very beautiful location of Mount Bromo.

articles.author: SalahElhossiny
articles.description:
Given a string paragraph and a string array of the banned words banned, return the most frequent word that is not banned. It is guaranteed there is at least one word that is not banned, and that the answer is unique.
The words in paragraph are case-insensitive and the answer should be returned in lowercase.

import re

class Solution:
    def mostCommonWord(self, paragraph: str, banned: List[str]) -> str:
        #List words in paragraph, replacing punctuation with ' ' and all lower case
        paragraph = re.subn("[.,!?;']", ' ', paragraph.lower())[0].split(' ')

        #Remove any '' or words in banned from paragraph list
        paragraph = list(filter(lambda x: x not in banned + [''], paragraph))

        #Return most common word in filtered list
        return Counter(paragraph).most_common(1)[0][0]
articles.title: Most Common Word

articles.author: Aditya Singh
articles.description:
What are NFTs?


Non-fungible tokens (NFTs) are cryptographic assets on a blockchain that can be distinguished from one another by their distinctive identifying codes and metadata. A digital asset known as an NFT is a representation of a real-world item, such as artwork, music, in-game items, or films. They are regularly purchased and traded online in exchange for other cryptocurrencies, and they are typically encoded using the same software as many other cryptocurrencies.
The same kind of programming that is used to develop cryptocurrencies is typically used to create NFTs. These cryptographic assets are built on blockchain technology, to put it simply. They cannot be traded or exchanged in the same manner as other cryptographic assets.
NFT stands for a non-fungible token, which means tha‚Ä¶
articles.title: A Complete Guide to NFTs

Âë®ÂõõÔºåÊúâÁ®ãÂ∫èÂëòÂú®ÊóßÈáëÂ±±ÊèêËµ∑ËØâËÆºÔºåÁß∞ÂÖ∂‰ª£Ë°®Êï∞Áôæ‰∏áÂèØËÉΩÂèóÊØèÊúà 10 ÁæéÂÖÉÁöÑ Copilot ÊúçÂä°ÂΩ±ÂìçÁöÑ GitHub Áî®Êà∑„ÄÇËØ•ËØâËÆºÊó®Âú®ÊåëÊàò GitHub Copilot ÁöÑÂêàÊ≥ïÊÄß„ÄÇËØâËÆºÂØπË±°ÂåÖÊã¨ GitHub ÂÖ∂ÊâÄÊúâËÄÖÂæÆËΩØÔºå‰ª•Âèä‰∏∫ËØ•Â∑•ÂÖ∑Êèê‰æõÊîØÊåÅÁöÑ OpenAI„ÄÇËØ•ËØâËÆºËÆ§‰∏∫‚ÄúË¢´ÂëäÂ∑≤Áªè‰æµÁäØ‰∫ÜÂ§ßÈáèÂàõ‰ΩúËÄÖÁöÑÂêàÊ≥ïÊùÉÂà©ÔºåËøô‰∫õÂàõ‰ΩúËÄÖÂú® GitHub ‰∏äÊ†πÊçÆÊüê‰∫õÂºÄÊ∫êËÆ∏ÂèØËØÅÂèëÂ∏É‰ª£Á†ÅÊàñÂÖ∂‰ªñ‰ΩúÂìÅ„ÄÇ‚ÄùÂåÖÊã¨ MIT ËÆ∏ÂèØËØÅ„ÄÅGPL ËÆ∏ÂèØËØÅÂíå Apache ËÆ∏ÂèØËØÅÁ≠â 11 ‰∏™ÊµÅË°åÁöÑÂºÄÊ∫êËÆ∏ÂèØËØÅÔºåÈÉΩË¶ÅÊ±ÇÊ≥®Êòé‰ΩúËÄÖÂßìÂêçÂíåÁâàÊùÉ„ÄÇCopilot ËøùÂèçÂπ∂Âà†Èô§Ëøô‰∫õËÆ∏ÂèØËØÅÔºå‚ÄúÂõ†Ê≠§ÔºåÂÆÉÊ≠£Âú®ÂÆûÊñΩËßÑÊ®°Á©∫ÂâçÁöÑËΩØ‰ª∂ÁõóÁâàË°å‰∏∫„ÄÇ‚Äù


Ê∂àÊÅØÊù•Ê∫êÔºöIT Pro



ËÄÅÁéãÁÇπËØÑÔºöËôΩÁÑ∂ÂèØËÉΩÊòØÊó∑Êó•ÊåÅ‰πÖÁöÑËØâËÆºÔºå‰ΩÜÊòØÁõÆÂâçÁöÑ AI Ê≤°ÊúâÁêÜ‰ºöÂºÄÊ∫êËÆ∏ÂèØËØÅÂ∞±Áõ¥Êé•ÊãøËøáÊù•Áî®‰ª£Á†ÅÁöÑÊñπÂºèÔºåËÇØÂÆöÊòØÊúâÈóÆÈ¢òÁöÑ„ÄÇ




ÁªèËøáÂÖ≠Âπ¥Á≠âÂæÖÔºåRust Áªà‰∫éÊîØÊåÅÈÄöÁî®ÂÖ≥ËÅîÁ±ªÂûã‰∫Ü

ÊúÄÊñ∞ÁöÑ Rust Á®≥ÂÆöÁâà 1.65.0 ÊîØÊåÅ‰∫ÜÈÄöÁî®ÂÖ≥ËÅîÁ±ªÂûãÔºàGATÔºâÔºåÂèØ‰ª•Âú®ÂÖ≥ËÅîÁ±ªÂûã‰∏äÂ£∞ÊòéÁîüÂëΩÊúü„ÄÅÁ±ªÂûãÂíåÂ∏∏ÈáèÊ≥õÂûã„ÄÇRust ÂÆòÊñπÁß∞Ôºå‚ÄúÂæàÈöæÁî®Âá†‰∏™Â≠óÊù•ÂΩ¢ÂÆπËøô‰∫õ‰∏úË•øÊúâÂ§öÊúâÁî®„ÄÇ‚Äù‰∏∫‰∫ÜÊîØÊåÅ GATÔºåÂøÖÈ°ªÂØπÁºñËØëÂô®ËøõË°åÂ§ßÈáèÁöÑ‰øÆÊîπÔºåËÄåËøôÈ°πÂäüËÉΩÁöÑ RFC ÊòØ 2016 Âπ¥ÊèêÂá∫ÁöÑ„ÄÇÊÄªÁöÑÊù•ËØ¥ÔºåGAT ‰∏∫Â§ßÈáèÁöÑÊ®°ÂºèÂíå API Êèê‰æõ‰∫ÜÂü∫Á°ÄÊÄßÁöÑ‰æùÊçÆ„ÄÇÂ§ßÈáèÈ°πÁõÆÂõ†‰∏∫ GAT ÁöÑÁ®≥ÂÆöËÄåÂèóÈòª„ÄÇÂç≥‰Ωø‰Ω†‰∏çÈúÄË¶ÅÁõ¥Êé•‰ΩøÁî® GATÔºå‰Ω†ÊâÄ‰ΩøÁî®ÁöÑÂ∫ì‰πüÂæàÊúâÂèØËÉΩÂú®ÂÜÖÈÉ®ÊàñÂÖ¨ÂºÄÂú∫Âêà‰ΩøÁî®ÂÆÉÔºåÂæàÂ§öÊó∂ÂÄôÔºåGAT ÊòØÂîØ‰∏ÄÂÆûÁé∞ÊñπÂºè„ÄÇ


Ê∂àÊÅØÊù•Ê∫êÔºöSlashdot



ËÄÅÁéãÁÇπËØÑÔºöRust Ë∂äÊù•Ë∂äÂèëÂ±ïÂÆåÂñÑÔºåÁúüÁöÑÂèØ‰ª•È¢ÑÊúüÊàê‰∏∫‰∏ªË¶ÅÁöÑÂ∫ïÂ±ÇËØ≠Ë®Ä„ÄÇ




Ë∞∑Ê≠åËÆ°ÂàíÂª∫Á´ãÊîØÊåÅ‰∏ñÁïå‰∏ä 1000 ÁßçÊúÄÂ∏∏Áî®ÁöÑËØ≠Ë®ÄÁöÑ AI Ê®°Âûã

ÂÆâÂçìÁöÑ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÈáçË¶ÅËøõÂ±ïÊòØÂ∞ÜÂÆâÂçìÂºÄÊ∫êÈ°πÁõÆAndroid Open Source ProjectÔºàAOSPÔºâÁßªÊ§çÂà∞ RISC-V Â§ÑÁêÜÂô®Êû∂ÊûÑ„ÄÇ




AOSP Â∑≤ÁªèÂºÄÂßãÂú®‰∏äÊ∏∏ÂêØÁî® RISC-VÔºåËøôÂ∞Ü‰øÉËøõ RISC-V CPU Âú®ÂèØÁ©øÊà¥ËÆæÂ§á„ÄÅÁâ©ËÅîÁΩëÔºå‰ª•ÂèäÊúÄÁªàÂú®Êô∫ËÉΩÊâãÊú∫ÂíåÁ¨îËÆ∞Êú¨ÁîµËÑë‰∏≠ÁöÑ‰ΩøÁî®„ÄÇ

‰∏∫‰∫ÜÂºÄÊîæÁîüÊÄÅÁ≥ªÁªüÔºå‰∏≠ÂõΩÁßëÂ≠¶Èô¢ PLCT ÂÆûÈ™åÂÆ§ÁöÑÂ∑•Á®ãÂ∏àÂíåËΩØ‰ª∂ÂºÄÂèë‰∫∫ÂëòÂú® 2020 Âπ¥ÂºÄÂßãÂ∞Ü Android 10 ÁßªÊ§çÂà∞ RISC-V Êû∂ÊûÑ‰∏ä„ÄÇÈòøÈáåÂ∑¥Â∑¥ÁöÑ‰∫ëËÆ°ÁÆóÈÉ®Èó®ÂíåÂπ≥Â§¥Âì•ËäØÁâáÂ≠êÂÖ¨Âè∏‰∏ÄËµ∑Âä™Âäõ‰øùÊåÅÂºÄÂèë‰∏éÊúÄÊñ∞ÁöÑÂÆâÂçìÁâàÊú¨ÂêåÊ≠•„ÄÇ

‚ÄúÊàë‰ª¨ÂæàÈ´òÂÖ¥ÁúãÂà∞Ë∞∑Ê≠åÂØπÊûÑÂª∫ÈíàÂØπ RISC-V ÁöÑ AOSP ÁöÑÊõ¥Â§öÊîØÊåÅÔºÅÈòøÈáå‰∫ë‰∏ÄÁõ¥Ëá¥Âäõ‰∫éÈÄöËøá‰∏ÄÁ≥ªÂàóÁöÑÂàõÊñ∞Êù•ÊîØÊåÅ RISC-V Á§æÂå∫ÁöÑÂèëÂ±ïÔºåÊØîÂ¶ÇÂ∞ÜÂÆâÂçìÁöÑÂü∫Êú¨ÂäüËÉΩÁßªÊ§çÂà∞ RISC-V ‰∏äÔºåËøôËØÅÊòé‰∫ÜÂú®‰ªéÂ§öÂ™í‰ΩìÂà∞‰ø°Âè∑Â§ÑÁêÜ„ÄÅËÆæÂ§á‰∫íËÅîÂíå‰∫∫Â∑•Êô∫ËÉΩÁ≠âÂú∫ÊôØ‰∏≠‰ΩøÁî®Âü∫‰∫é RISC-V ÁöÑËÆæÂ§áÁöÑÂèØË°åÊÄß„ÄÇ‚ÄùÈòøÈáå‰∫ëÁîüÊÄÅÁ≥ªÁªüÊÄªÁõë„ÄÅRISC-V ÂõΩÈôÖÁªÑÁªáÁöÑÂ∫îÁî®‰∏éÂ∑•ÂÖ∑Ê∞¥Âπ≥ÂßîÂëò‰ºöÂâØ‰∏ªÂ∏≠ David Chen ÂçöÂ£´ËØ¥Ôºö‚ÄúÊàë‰ª¨ÊúüÂæÖÁùÄ‰∏éÂÆâÂçìÂõ¢ÈòüÂêà‰ΩúÔºå‰∏∫ÁπÅËç£ÁöÑ RISC-V Á§æÂå∫ÂÅöÂá∫Ë¥°ÁåÆ„ÄÇ‚Äù

ÈÄöËøáÂ¢ûÂº∫ RISC-V ‰∏äÁöÑÂÆâÂçìÁ≥ªÁªüÁöÑÂü∫Êú¨ÂäüËÉΩÔºåÂú® 2021 Âπ¥ÔºåÈòøÈáå‰∫ëÁöÑ‰∏ìÂÆ∂‰ª¨‰ªòÂá∫‰∫ÜÂ∑®Â§ßÁöÑÂä™ÂäõÔºåÁßØÊûÅÊé®Âä®‰∫ÜËΩØ‰ª∂ÁîüÊÄÅÁ≥ªÁªüÁöÑÂèëÂ±ï„ÄÇ RISC-V on Android ÁöÑÂ∑•‰ΩúÈõÜ‰∏≠Âú® RISC-V Android Â∑•‰ΩúÁªÑÂíåËΩØ‰ª∂Â∫ì‰∏≠ËøõË°å„ÄÇ

articles.description:
git log¬†ÂëΩ‰ª§ÊòØ Git ‰∏≠‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂæàÈáçË¶ÅÁöÑÊü•ÁúãÊèê‰∫§ËÆ∞ÂΩïÁöÑÂ∑•ÂÖ∑ÔºåÂÆÉ‰πüÊòØ‰∫∫‰ª¨ÂñúÊ¨¢‰ΩøÁî® Git ÁöÑÂéüÂõ†‰πã‰∏Ä„ÄÇ


git log¬†ÂëΩ‰ª§ËÉΩÂ§üËÆ©‰Ω†‰∫ÜËß£Âà∞Êõ¥Â§öÂÖ≥‰∫éË¥°ÁåÆËÄÖ¬†Êèê‰∫§commit¬†ÁöÑËÆ∞ÂΩï„ÄÇ‰ΩøÁî®¬†git log¬†ÁöÑ‰∏ÄÁßçÊñπÂºèÊòØÊåâÊó•ÊúüÊü•ÁúãÊèê‰∫§ËÆ∞ÂΩï „ÄÇË¶ÅÊü•ÁúãÂú®ÊåáÂÆöÊó•ÊúüÊàñÊó•ÊúüËåÉÂõ¥ÂÜÖÂàõÂª∫ÁöÑ Git Â≠òÂÇ®Â∫ì‰∏≠ÁöÑÊèê‰∫§ËÆ∞ÂΩïÔºåËØ∑‰ΩøÁî®Â∏¶ÊúâÈÄâÈ°π¬†--since¬†Êàñ¬†--until¬†ÊàñËÄÖÂêåÊó∂‰ΩøÁî®‰ª•‰∏ä‰∏§‰∏™ÈÄâÈ°πÁöÑ¬†git log¬†ÂëΩ‰ª§„ÄÇ

È¶ñÂÖàÔºåËøõÂÖ•‰Ω†Ë¶ÅÊü•ÁúãÁöÑÂàÜÊîØÔºà‰æãÂ¶ÇÔºåmain¬†ÂàÜÊîØÔºâÔºö

$ git checkout main


Êé•‰∏ãÊù•Ôºå‰Ω†ÂèØ‰ª•‰ΩøÁî®‰ª•‰∏ãÂëΩ‰ª§ÔºåÊù•ÊòæÁ§∫ÂΩìÂâçÊó•ÊúüÔºàÂç≥‰ªäÂ§©ÔºâÁöÑÊèê‰∫§ËÆ∞ÂΩïÔºö

$ git log --oneline --since="yesterday"


‰ªÖÊòæÁ§∫Êüê‰∏ÄÁâπÂÆöÁî®Êà∑Ôºà‰æãÂ¶ÇÔºåÁî®Êà∑¬†AgilÔºâÂú®‰ªäÂ§©ÁöÑÊèê‰∫§ËÆ∞ÂΩïÔºö

$ git log --oneline --since="yesterday" --author="Agil"


ËøòÂèØ‰ª•ÊòæÁ§∫Âú®Êüê‰∏ÄÊó•ÊúüËåÉÂõ¥ÂÜÖÁöÑÊèê‰∫§ËÆ∞ÂΩï„ÄÇ‰ΩøÁî®‰ª•‰∏ãÂëΩ‰ª§ÔºåÊòæÁ§∫Âú®‰ªªÊÑè‰∏§‰∏™Êó•Êúü‰πãÈó¥Ôºà‰æãÂ¶ÇÔºå2022 Âπ¥ 4 Êúà 22 Êó•Ëá≥ 2022 Âπ¥ 4 Êúà 24 Êó•ÔºâÁöÑÊèê‰∫§ËÆ∞ÂΩïÔºö

$ git log --oneline --since="2022-04-22" --until="2022-04-24"


Âú®‰∏äÈù¢Ëøô‰∏™‰æãÂ≠ê‰∏≠Ôºå‰ºöËæìÂá∫ 2022 Âπ¥ 4 Êúà 22 Êó•Ëá≥ 2022 Âπ¥ 4 Êúà 24 Êó•ÊúüÈó¥Ôºå‰∏çÂåÖÊã¨ 2022 Âπ¥ 4 Êúà 22 Êó•ÁöÑÊâÄÊúâÊèê‰∫§ËÆ∞ÂΩï„ÄÇÂ¶ÇÊûú‰Ω†ÊÉ≥Ë¶ÅÂåÖÊã¨ 2022 Âπ¥ 4 Êúà 22 Êó•ÁöÑÊèê‰∫§ËÆ∞ÂΩïÔºåËØ∑Â∞ÜÂëΩ‰ª§‰∏≠ÁöÑ¬†2022-04-22¬†ÊõøÊç¢‰∏∫¬†2022-04-21„ÄÇ

ËøêË°å‰ª•‰∏ãÂëΩ‰ª§ÔºåËÉΩÂ§üÊòæÁ§∫Êüê‰∏ÄÁâπÂÆöÁî®Êà∑Ôºà‰æãÂ¶ÇÔºåÁî®Êà∑¬†AgilÔºâÂú®‰∏§‰∏™ÊåáÂÆöÁöÑÊó•Êúü‰πãÈó¥ÁöÑÊèê‰∫§ËÆ∞ÂΩïÔºö

$ git log --oneline --since="2022-04-22" --until="2022-04-24" --author="Agil"


ÊÄªÁªì

Git ÊúâÂæàÂ§ö‰ºòÁÇπÔºåÂÖ∂‰∏≠‰∏Ä‰∏™‰ºòÁÇπÂ∞±ÊòØ Git ËÆ©‰Ω†ËÉΩÂ§üÊî∂ÈõÜ‰Ω†È°πÁõÆÁöÑÁõ∏ÂÖ≥Êï∞ÊçÆ„ÄÇgit log¬†ÂëΩ‰ª§ÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÈáçË¶ÅÁöÑÊü•ÁúãÊèê‰∫§ËÆ∞ÂΩïÁöÑÂ∑•ÂÖ∑Ôºå‰πüÊòØ‰∫∫‰ª¨ÂñúÊ¨¢‰ΩøÁî® Git ÁöÑÂéüÂõ†‰πã‰∏ÄÔºÅ


via:¬†https://opensource.com/article/22/10/git-log-command

‰ΩúËÄÖÔºöAgil Antony¬†ÈÄâÈ¢òÔºölkxed¬†ËØëËÄÖÔºöchai001125¬†Ê†°ÂØπÔºöwxy

Êú¨ÊñáÁî±¬†LCTT¬†ÂéüÂàõÁºñËØëÔºåLinux‰∏≠ÂõΩ¬†Ëç£Ë™âÊé®Âá∫

Years ago while rummaging through the contents of a shelf in a used bookstore, I happened upon a booklet titled "UNIX System Command Summary for Berkeley 4.2 & 4.3 BSD," published by¬†Specialized Systems Consultants. I bought it as a curiosity item because it was nearly 20 years old yet still largely applicable to modern Linux and BSD.
That amused me then and now. A booklet written in 1986 was still largely relevant in 2016, while books on the same shelf about a proprietary OS weren't worth the paper they were printed on. (Think about it: What technology do¬†you¬†think is going to survive a zombie apocalypse?) I've had the booklet on my own bookshelf for several years now, but it occurred to me that it's pro‚Ä¶

articles.author: Seth Kenlon
articles.description:
Is Lua worth learning?
Seth Kenlon
Thu, 11/03/2022 - 03:00

            
Lua is a scripting language used for procedural programming, functional programming, and even object-oriented programming. It uses a C-like syntax, but is dynamically typed, features automatic memory management and garbage collection, and runs by interpreting bytecode with a register-based virtual machine. This makes it a great language for beginners, but also a powerful tool for experienced programmers.
Lua has been somewhat eclipsed from the public view by languages like Python and JavaScript, but Lua has several advantages that make it popular in some major software projects. Lua is easily embedded within other languages, meaning that you can include Lua files in the code base of something written in (for instance)‚Ä¶
articles.title: Is Lua worth learning?

articles.author: Phil Shapiro
articles.description:
How open source weaves connections between countries
Phil Shapiro
Thu, 11/03/2022 - 03:00

            
Long ago, when I was a tech administrator for Arlington Public Schools, I received an unexpected email saying, "Our school in India loves your children's stories, so we've printed them all out in braille."
Apparently, the school had found my collection of children's stories on the web. I spent a moment visualizing those students so far away, enjoying my stories on those printed pages of braille. The email's sender might not have realized how meaningful their email was to me, but it's stayed with me for two decades.
Tell collaborative stories with open source
That experience got me thinking about how technology can weave new connections between people in different countries. While surfing‚Ä¶

Florian Robert
Wed, 11/02/2022 - 03:00

            
Advertisers sell the myth of the "Smart Home" as a magical world where you automate everything with ease to simplify your life and free your mind of trivial tasks. It looks great on paper and TV, but so far, it's mainly been a battle of technologies and manufacturers.
Suppose you want to add a presence sensor from manufacturer A to your existing hub from manufacturer B so you can switch ON your light from manufacturer B. Or perhaps you want to switch OFF your air conditioner when your door is open, but the door sensor is not from the air conditioning manufacturer. Will it work?
There's a significant chance that the devices you want to link to one another don't talk the same ‚Ä¶

Nitish Tiwari
Tue, 11/01/2022 - 03:00

            
Log data is one of the fastest-growing segments across data storage. It's also one of the most complicated spaces. There are several products and solutions with overlapping use cases and confusing marketing.
This article looks at Parseable, a log storage and observability platform. Parseable is geared towards a better user experience, with an easy-to-deploy and use interface and a simple, cloud-native architecture. I'll also show how to set up Parseable with FluentBit to store logs.

articles.description:
Transfer files and folders from Windows to Linux with WinSCP
Paul
Tue, 11/01/2022 - 03:00

            
Sometimes you need to transfer files over a network. There are lots of file sharing services out there, but most require that you send your file to the Internet. This seems like a long way to go (not to mention the privacy concerns) when two computers are right beside each other, or at least in the same building. The open source WinSCP utility makes it quick and easy to transfer a file or a folder of files over the network from your Windows computer to your Linux computer.

articles.author: Martin Kopec
articles.description:
10 universal steps for open source code review
Martin Kopec
Mon, 10/31/2022 - 03:00

            
Have you ever found yourself in a situation where you needed to do a code review but didn't fully understand the project? Maybe you did not review it to avoid looking like you didn't know what you were doing.
This article assures you that there's a better way. You don't need to know everything to provide a code review. In fact, based on my experience, that's quite common.
I remember when I joined Red Hat as an intern and was asked to help with code reviews. We used a system of +1 or -1 votes, and I was initially very hesitant to weigh in. I found myself asking whether when I gave a +1 on a change but then someone else voted -1, would I look foolish?
What does happen if someone votes -1 on a ch‚Ä¶

articles.author: Seth Kenlon
articles.description:
Set up a Matrix to Discord bot
Seth Kenlon
Sat, 10/29/2022 - 03:00

            
Matrix is a popular open source chat application that makes it easy to chat securely with people all over the world. Similarly, Discord is a non-open source chat application that's also popular with many online communities. Discord, like Matrix, provides a chat client for all major platforms both mobile and desktop, so it's perfectly usable on Linux. However, it's not open source and so, given the choice, you might prefer to use Matrix. The good news is that when not given a choice for any reason, you can also use Matrix to interface with Discord by running a Matrix-to-Discord bridge. This article shows you how to set up and run a Python Matrix bot to bridge chat between a Matrix room and a Discord channel.
Re‚Ä¶
articles.title: Set up a Matrix to Discord bot

articles.description:
Kuiq - the way you ship your API in 10 sec ‚ö°

Why did I make Kuiq?
I am looking to complete the product as quickly as possible, especially for MVP stuff. And I'm sure you all have the same opinion üòó

When deploying APIs, whether Firebase or AWS, I think you need to create a project and configure it in advance. When you are making an MVP for a product, this kind of hassle is very disturbing :/

Kuiq eliminates all of this hassle and allows you to deploy your API as soon as you log in to Kuiq üòÅ

Is this the same as Deno Deploy?
Almost same. But different pricing model.

Future of Kuiq
‚úçÔ∏è Create a VSCode extension so code can be sent directly from VSCode to Kuiq

ü§ñ API with Database concept (not sure yet)
When we do backend processing with API, we often want to manipulate the database.
For example, storing customer email data.
So I thought that having a database connected to an API that can be easily deployed might speed up the development of the product :)

Looking forward to your thought! 
Try it out over here üëâ https://kuiq.io/
              ‚Äù

@packwhale) and I‚Äôm thrilled to launch today on Product Hunt!!!
About me: I‚Äôve been working in online marketing for nearly a decade and I‚Äôve always been curious about new tools that can make my life as a marketer easier.

I‚Äôve often seen people stare at their Google Analytics dashboard without really doing something actionable or meaningful to understand what‚Äôs going on with their data. 

So I created the Google Analytics Pack for Coda to analyze my data, generate notes, and facilitate discussions with my team so we improve our website‚Äôs performance. You can even set up automations when you hit milestones‚Äîlike Slacking your team when web traffic hits 1M views. Here‚Äôs a glimpse of what you can do:

‚úÖ Use cases: 
* Build and share custom reports for your team and stakeholders. 
* Invite your team to analyze your website‚Äôs performance together.
* Make data-based decisions, plan your marketing campaigns, and build custom automations for your data. 

Special thanks to the @coda_hq team for their support üôå
